Come along, Tocqueville, A little more brandy. You will never

are first fortified with an American breakfast I
No, thank you, I^m not hungry; I mean, thirsty*
Come, come, Tocqueville, you must bring your mind back from
France, This is July the Fourth, not July the Fourteenth;
Independence Day, not Bastille Day^ We are about to witness
the National Celebration of a happy Democracy.
And how much of this happiness and democracy can we teach to
France? Do the two go together? I wish I knew. Bequmont,
last year I saw with my own eyes the carriage go by in the rain
that took Charles the Tenth into exile: Charles the Tenth, Louis
the Sixteenth^ own brother: the very last of the Bourbons;
the very last of the absolute monarchs. Now we have a
constitutional monarch; now we have the beginnings of democracy *
Will that make us a happy and contented people, Beaumont?
